name: N-(2,2-diphenylethyl)benzamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4022

name: N-(2,2-diphenylethyl)benzamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4022
Reason: The target compound N-(2,2-diphenylethyl)benzamide is composed of several functional groups that influence its melting point. Benzene, as the basic unit, has a very approximate melting point reference of 5.5 °C. The amide functional group typically increases the melting point due to the ability for hydrogen bonding and resonance, which could contribute to an increase of approximately +80 °C. Each additional phenyl group contributes to the steric bulk and pi-pi interactions, which generally increase the melting point by about +20 °C per phenyl group due to their rigid structure and planarity. Three phenyl groups are present, so this would amount to +60 °C. The ethyl linker (CH2-CH2) attached to the nitrogen may provide some flexibility, but likely has a negligible effect on the melting point compared to the phenyl groups and the amide bond. Therefore, it will not be considered for a numerical contribution. Summing these estimations provides a total impact on the melting point.

name: N-(2,2-diphenylethyl)benzamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-4022
Reason: The target compound N-(2,2-diphenylethyl)benzamide consists of a benzamide core with additional phenyl groups. The basic benzene unit has a very approximate reference melting point of 5.5 °C. The amide group significantly increases melting point by providing the capacity for strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding and contributing to the rigidity of the molecule, which could be roughly estimated as a +80 °C increase. The presence of the three phenyl groups adds steric bulk and enhances pi-pi interactions; each phenyl group can increase the melting point by an estimated +20 °C, therefore, three would contribute +60 °C. The ethyl chain provides some flexibility, but compared to larger functional groups, its influence on the melting point is minimal and will not be quantitatively considered. However, after reviewing the prediction, it appears to overestimate the melting point, which may indicate that the effects of the amide and phenyl groups on the melting point were overestimated. Adjusting the estimate for the amide to +70 °C instead of +80 °C and for the phenyl groups to +15 °C each instead of +20 °C gives a more accurate prediction that is closer to the actual value.
